G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may modify custody orders when a material change in circumstances occurs, and the modification is in the child’s best interests.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6 because the original custody order was entered in this Court, and the Plaintiff and child continue to reside in Middlesex County.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The Plaintiff submits that this modification is necessary and consistent with the best interests of the child as interpreted under Massachusetts law, including *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) and *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition invokes Yannas for the Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ standard in the context of a requested modification (here, a relocation/removal-type change). Yannas directly articulates how the best interests standard operates in removal cases, adopting the ‘real advantage’ framework and explaining that the child’s best interests are assessed in light of the custodial parent’s circumstances. Thus, it is an appropriate and accurate authority for a modification argued as consistent with the child’s best interests under Massachusetts law.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life)…” (395 Mass. at 710–11).

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Plaintiff submits that this modification is necessary and consistent with the best interests of the child as interpreted under Massachusetts law, including *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) and *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the requested modification (a relocation/removal determination) must be consistent with the child’s best interests as interpreted under Massachusetts law, including Yannas and Mason. Mason squarely addresses the standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30 when parents share joint legal and physical custody, and holds that “cause shown” means a showing that removal is in the child’s best interests, taking into account all circumstances. Thus, it is proper authority for citing the best-interests framework governing relocation/modification decisions in Massachusetts.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, governs removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents… Removal of the children may be authorized by the court only ‘upon cause shown,’ meaning a showing that removal is in the children’s best interests… Today we consider the appropriate standard where parents have joint physical and legal custody. We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493-494.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may modify custody orders when a material change in circumstances occurs, and the modification is in the child’s best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493-494.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the best-interests standard and cites G.L. c. 208, § 31, but it does not address G.L. c. 208, § 28 or the standard for *modification* of an existing custody order after a material change in circumstances. The custody discussion concerns an initial custody determination between two legal parents, not a post-judgment modification proceeding. Therefore, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about modifying custody orders under § 28.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 493-494.relevant_excerpt: Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. See Commonwealth v. Beals, 405 Mass. 550, 554 (1989). "In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is 'best for the child' . . . ." Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). ... The judge shall consider "whether or not the child's present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health." G. L. c. 208, § 31.

*Ducharme v. Ducharme*, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The Court has consistently found that lengthy travel times and disruptions to school routines are detrimental to a child’s well-being.
*Ducharme v. Ducharme*, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal case about admission of prior bad acts and ineffective assistance of counsel, not a family law or custody/visitation decision. It nowhere discusses children’s travel time, commuting burdens, or disruptions to school routines, nor does it make findings about such factors being detrimental to a child’s well-being. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition claimed.
*Ducharme v. Ducharme*, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: At the time when the abuse began, N.M. lived in Boston. When she was thirteen years old, N.M. moved to Dover, where the sexual abuse underlying the defendant’s convictions took place. The defendant properly does not raise any issue on appeal related to the uncharged sexual assaults.

*Mickelson v. Barnet*, 49 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court has consistently found that lengthy travel times and disruptions to school routines are detrimental to a child’s well-being.
*Mickelson v. Barnet*, 49 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about the admissibility of a defendant’s prior trial testimony, self-defense, and related constitutional and evidentiary issues. It does not concern custody, visitation, school choice, or any discussion of children, travel time, or school routines. Therefore it cannot be authority for the proposition about lengthy travel times and disruptions to school routines being detrimental to a child’s well-being.

*R.H. v. B.F.*, 102 Mass. App. Ct. 508,.proposition: Sophie's expressed anxiety and disruption to her school and extracurricular activities further demonstrate that the current arrangement no longer serves her best interests.

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 548.proposition: This modification is consistent with Massachusetts law, which favors stability, continuity, and the minimization of harm to the child.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 548.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly frames the statutory scheme as giving primacy to the child’s stability and condemns the judge’s actions for significantly disrupting that stability. It approvingly cites Custody of Kali for the principle that maintaining an existing parenting arrangement and avoiding unnecessary disruption is ordinarily in the child’s best interests, emphasizing stability and minimizing harm. Thus, the opinion supports the proposition that Massachusetts law favors stability, continuity, and minimizing harm to the child in custody and relocation contexts.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 548.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) (‘If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child’).”

*El Chaar v. Chehab*, 78 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: *El Chaar v. Chehab*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 501, 503-506 (2010)
*El Chaar v. Chehab*, 78 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: This modification is consistent with Massachusetts law, which favors stability, continuity, and the minimization of harm to the child.
*El Chaar v. Chehab*, 78 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case is primarily about whether a Lebanese custody judgment is in substantial conformity with Massachusetts law, but in that context it describes the Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ standard. In setting out the constant factors in that analysis, the court expressly includes “the need for stability and continuity in the child’s life,” showing that Massachusetts law favors those values when assessing custody and modifications. The opinion does not focus on modification doctrine generally, but it does link best interests (including stability/continuity) to both initial and modification custody orders.
*El Chaar v. Chehab*, 78 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Such constants, or factors, include, for example, consideration of which parent has been the primary caretaker of, and formed the strongest bonds with, the child, **the need for stability and continuity in the child’s life**, the decision-making capabilities of each parent to address the child’s needs, and the living arrangements and lifestyles of each parent and how such circumstances may affect the child. … This is true whether considering an original judgment awarding custody or a modification judgment showing changed circumstances; the guiding principle is always the best interests of the child.
